0.text:
Are wind and solar power the answer to our
energy needs? There’s a lot of sun

6.text:
and a lot of wind. They’re free. They’re clean.
No CO2 emissions. So, what’s the problem?

13.text:
Why do solar and wind combined provide less
than 2% of the world’s energy?

19.text:
To answer these questions, we need to understand
what makes energy, or anything else for that matter,

24.text:
cheap and plentiful.
For something to be cheap and plentiful,

28.text:
every part of the process to produce it, including
every input that goes into it,

34.text:
must be cheap and plentiful.
Yes, the sun is free. Yes, wind is free.

40.text:
But the process of turning sunlight and wind into
useable energy on a mass scale is far from free.

47.text:
In fact, compared to the other sources
of energy -- fossil fuels, nuclear power,

52.text:
and hydroelectric power, solar and wind power
are very expensive.

57.text:
The basic problem is that sunlight and wind
as energy sources are both weak

62.text:
(the more technical term is dilute) and unreliable (the
more technical term is intermittent).

68.text:
It takes a lot of resources to collect and concentrate
them, and even more resources to make them

73.text:
available on-demand. These are called the
diluteness problem and the intermittency problem.

80.text:
The diluteness problem is that, unlike coal
or oil, the sun and the wind don’t deliver

85.text:
concentrated energy -- which means you need
a lot of additional materials

90.text:
to produce a unit of energy.
For solar power, such materials can include

95.text:
highly purified silicon, phosphorus, boron,
and a dozen other complex compounds like titanium

101.text:
dioxide. All these materials have to be mined,
refined and/or manufactured in order to make

107.text:
solar panels. Those industrial processes take
a lot of energy.

112.text:
For wind, needed materials include high-performance
compounds for turbine blades and the rare-earth

118.text:
metal neodymium for lightweight, specialty
magnets, as well as the steel and concrete

123.text:
necessary to build structures -- thousands
of them -- as tall as skyscrapers.

127.text:
And as big a problem as diluteness is, it’s
nothing compared to the intermittency problem.

134.text:
This isn’t exactly a news flash, but the
sun doesn’t shine all the time.

137.text:
And the wind doesn’t blow all the time. The only
way for solar and wind to be truly useful

143.text:
would be if we could store them so that they
would be available when we needed them.

148.text:
You can store oil in a tank. Where do you store
solar or wind energy? No such mass-storage

154.text:
system exists. Which is why, in the entire
world, there is not one real or proposed independent,

160.text:
freestanding solar or wind power plant. All
of them require backup. And guess what the

166.text:
go-to back-up is: fossil fuel.
Here’s what solar and wind electricity look

171.text:
like in Germany, which is the world’s leader
in “renewables”. The word erratic leaps to mind.

178.text:
Wind is constantly varying, sometimes
disappearing completely.

182.text: And solar produces little in the winter months when Germany most needs energy.

186.text:
Therefore, some reliable source of energy
is needed to do the heavy lifting. In Germany’s

192.text:
case that energy is coal. So, while Germany
has spent tens of billions of dollars to subsidize

198.text:
solar panels and windmills, fossil fuel use
in that nation has not decreased, it’s increased

204.text:
-- and less than 10% of their total energy
is generated by solar and wind.

209.text:
Furthermore, switching back and forth between
solar and wind and coal to maintain a steady

215.text:
flow of energy is costly. Utility bills for
the average German have gone up so dramatically

221.text:
that “energy poverty” has become a popular
term to describe those who cannot pay

226.text:
-- or who can barely pay -- their electricity bills.
If those bills one day go down, the reason

232.text:
will not be more solar and wind energy, but
lower oil and coal prices.

237.text:
There’s no free lunch. And there’s no
free energy. And that very much includes the

243.text:
highly expensive energy from the sun and the
wind.

247.text:
I’m Alex Epstein of the Center for Industrial
Progress, for Prager University.
